facts.text: Lala Beni Pershad died in 1910 leaving widow Mst. Daropadi (defendant respondent No. 2) and two sons Gokul Chand (defendant respondent No. 1) and Raghunath Das (plaintiff appellant, then minor). Left considerable movable properties including G.P. Notes and immovable properties including agricultural land, gardens and houses.
Family continued joint until disputes arose between brothers in 1934.

On November 12, 1934, brothers executed agreement referring disputes on partition to arbitration of Lala Ramji Das, common relation. Alleged Gokul Chand disposed part of G.P. Notes; at reference, G.P. Notes worth Rs. 26,500 held by Gokul Chand as Karta.

Arbitrator made award on June 21, 1936, signed by both brothers. Divided immovable properties and shops. For G.P. Notes: Rs. 13,300 to Gokul Chand and Mst. Daropadi; Rs. 13,200 to Raghunath Das and Mst. Daropadi. Mst. Daropadi entitled to interest till death. Gokul Chand to pay Rs. 20,000 to Raghunath in four installments with interest. Award registered July 28, 1936.

On August 31, 1936, Gokul Chand applied to District Judge, Ambala under para 20 Sch II CPC to file award. During pendency, brothers compromise modifying award (details not material). District Judge on November 18, 1936 directed filing as modified and passed decree accordingly.
Raghunath Das applied for execution of decree on November 15, 1939. Transferred to Subordinate Judge who issued notice to Gokul Chand.

Gokul Chand objected to execution: decree passed without jurisdiction as District Judge had no power for partition of agricultural lands. Subordinate Judge on December 23, 1942 accepted and dismissed execution.
Raghunath Das appealed to High Court; Single Judge on April 5, 1944 accepted appeal. Gokul Chand's Letters Patent Appeal: Division Bench on March 15, 1945 reversed and restored dismissal.

Raghunath Das instituted Suit No. 80 of 1945 on August 21, 1945 against Gokul Chand for Rs. 7,310-11-3 balance with interest of Rs. 20,000. Senior Subordinate Judge decreed on December 22, 1945; no appeal, final.
Raghunath Das filed Suit No. 239 of 1946 on June 5, 1946 claiming Gokul Chand transfer G.P. Notes Rs. 13,200 (particulars given) to Raghunath and Mst. Daropadi or pay Rs. 13,200.
Subordinate Judge, Ambala decreed suit on July 1, 1947 in favor of plaintiff: suit within time (Art. 120, exclude Nov 15,1939-Mar15,1945 under s.14 Limitation Act); not barred O2 R2 CPC.
Gokul Chand appealed to Punjab High Court; Division Bench on April 22, 1952 reversed, dismissed suit as barred by Art. 49 Limitation Act.
Certificate granted by Division Bench on December 19, 1952 for appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Is the suit within time? (Art. 49 vs. Art. 120 of Limitation Act; applicability of s.14 Limitation Act)
Is the suit barred by Order 2 Rule 2 CPC?

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit governed by residuary Art. 120 Limitation Act (six years), not Art. 49 (specific movable). Period Nov 15,1939 to Mar 15,1945 excluded under s.14 Limitation Act. Cause of action in earlier suit (Rs.20,000) different from present suit.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 120, s.14 Limitation Act; O.2 R.2 CPC

respondent_arguments.text: Suit for recovery of specific movable property (G.P. Notes), governed by Art. 49 (three years from unlawful detention). Even excluding execution period, time-barred. Also barred by O.2 R.2 CPC.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 49 Limitation Act; O.2 R.2 CPC

court_reasoning.text: Decree only declared rights; no actual division of G.P. Notes specifying particular notes. Suit not for specific movable property under Art.49 but for partition/division of joint/tenants-in-common movable property, governed by Art.120. Gokul's possession not wrongful till actual partition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Brothers entitled as joint coparceners then tenants-in-common; no specific Article for such partition suit, hence Art.120.

court_reasoning.text: Execution proceedings prosecuted with due diligence, good faith, same cause of action (enforce decree rights), court lacked jurisdiction (defect attached from passing court). Entire period Nov15,1939-Mar15,1945 excluded under s.14(1) Limitation Act. Suit within time.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Single Judge upheld jurisdiction initially; Division Bench found decree nullity for want of jurisdiction.

court_reasoning.text: High Court did not decide O.2 R.2 issue; remand required.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Finding on limitation disposes suit but other issue pending.

holdings.text: Suit not governed by Art.49 but Art.120 Limitation Act; time excluded under s.14(1); not time-barred.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gopal Chandra Bose v. Surendra Nath Dutt
precedents_cited.relevance: Defendant had no right/interest in G.P. Notes there; unlike here where joint till partition.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mohomed Riasat Ali v. Mussumat Hasin Banu
precedents_cited.relevance: Suit by heir for share of movable estate not under Art.49 but Art.120; similar principle applies post-decree declaration.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.49 inapplicable to partition suit; Art.120 residuary; s.14 excludes time in prior failed proceedings for jurisdiction defect.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Filing award/decree; bar on omitting relief from prior suit.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside High Court judgment dismissing suit as time-barred, held suit within limitation under Art.120 with s.14 exclusion, remanded to High Court for decision on O.2 R.2 issue.
outcome.relief_granted: Remand to High Court for determination of issue No.3 (O.2 R.2 bar)

key_quotes.text: Until the G.P. Notes were actually divided... neither of the brothers could claim any particular piece of G.P. Notes as his separate property...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why suit not for 'specific movable property' under Art.49.

key_quotes.text: a suit by an heir against other heirs to recover his share of the moveable estate... is not one for specific moveable property... but is governed by Art. 120.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding applying precedent to facts.
